headline: China taps private sector for sci-tech leaders in expanded academic recruitment drive | South China Morning Post
context: China has launched an unprecedented drive to recruit leading scientific and technological experts for its top academic institutions – expanding the selection quota and, for the first time, granting dedicated access to private-sector researchers.

The Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS) and Chinese Academy of Engineering (CAE) began the biannual nomination process last week for leading academic staff, or yuanshi – the country’s highest academic title, awarded only to top scientists and engineers.

annotations.paragraph: Both academies aimed to enrol up to 100 new academic members each in this round, according to statements last week, marking the largest such hiring spree in at least a decade.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the scale of the recruitment drive, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The CAE designated eight slots to “support candidates from leading private tech firms”, it said in its announcement.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives specific information about the allocation of slots for private tech firms, directly related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: In another statement, the CAE stressed that these academic nominations would prioritise experts from leading tech companies, particularly the private sector, and suggested that about 30 per cent of candidates would come from “corporate research front lines”.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant details about the prioritization of private sector experts in the recruitment process.
